subject: AW: [junit] Problem accessing weblogic using JNDI
msgSnippet: There have been many postings regarding this problem. It s due to Junit s custom ClassLoader. the simplest possibility, start your TestCase or Suite like this:
messageBody:
There have been many postings regarding this problem. It's due to Junit's
custom ClassLoader.

the simplest possibility, start your TestCase or Suite like this:

junit.swingui.TestRunner.main(new String[] {
MyTestCase.class.getName(), "-noloading" } );



> -----Urspr√ºngliche Nachricht-----
> Von: knollenberger@... [mailto:knollenberger@...]
> Gesendet: Friday, May 04, 2001 7:58 PM
> An: junit@yahoogroups.com
> Betreff: [junit] Problem accessing weblogic using JNDI
>
>
> I am having trouble accessing an EJB deployed in Weblogic 6.0 sith
> servicepack , using a JNDI call.
>
> If I run this method:
>
> public static void testDummyService() throws Exception{
> String testString = "four";
> int expectedLength = 4;
>
> AutomationSessionHome automationSessionHome =
> (AutomationSessionHome) JndiUtil.lookupHome(
>
> AUTOMATION_JNDI_NAME);
>
> AutomationSession automationSession = (AutomationSession)
> PortableRemoteObject.narrow(automationSessionHome.create(),
>
> AutomationSession.class);
> int receivedLength =
> automationSession.dummyService(testString);
> automationSession.remove();
> assertEquals("Received string length is different
> than expected",
> expectedLength, receivedLength);
> }
>
>
>
> from the main method. It works fine. It also works fine if
> I use JUnit 3.2
> to call this method. However, if I use Junit 3.4 or 3.5 or
> 3.6, I get a
> ClassCastException on this line:
>
> AutomationSession automationSession = (AutomationSession)
> PortableRemoteObject.narrow(automationSessionHome.create(),
>
> AutomationSession.class);
>
> I know that I am getting the right object back from the
> server. I'm not
> sure why I am getting this exception.
>
> Any Suggestions?
>
